articles.title: Mandiant releases quick credential cracker, to hasten the death of a bad protocol
articles.summary:
PLUS: Navy spy sent to brig for 200 months in brig; Black Axe busted again; Bill aims to crimp ICE apps; and more

Infosec In Brief  PLUS: Google’s security outfit Mandiant last week released tools that can crack credentials in 12 hours, in the hope that doing so will accelerate the death of an ancient Microsoft security protocol.…
articles.reasoning: The article discusses Mandiant releasing tools to crack credentials in a legacy Microsoft protocol, highlighting security weaknesses and urging organizations to disable it, which relates to IT governance through security policy enforcement and technology lifecycle management.

articles.title: Not hot on bots, project names and shames AI-created open source software
articles.summary:
'OpenSlopware' briefly flowers, fades, falls – but fortunately was forked, fast

The splendidly-named "OpenSlopware" was, for a short time, a list of open source projects using LLM bots. Due to harassment, it's gone, but forks of it live on.…
articles.reasoning: The article discusses open source projects using AI-generated code and the governance challenges around tracking, listing, and maintaining such projects, including issues of harassment and repository management.

articles.title: S Twatter: When text-to-speech goes down the drain
articles.summary:
Rinse of the machines: A cautionary tale about relying on robots

Bork!Bork!Bork!  UK water company Severn Trent learned an unfortunate lesson about text-to-speech systems when a robocall to customers went hilariously wrong.…
articles.reasoning: The incident illustrates a failure to realize intended benefits from a technology investment, as the automated system produced unintended and potentially damaging outcomes instead of effective customer communication.

articles.title: Sorry Dave, I’m afraid I can’t do that! PCs refuse to shut down after Microsoft patch
articles.summary:
Microsoft claims it's a Secure Launch bug

We're not saying Copilot has become sentient and decided it doesn't want to lose consciousness. But if it did, it would create Microsoft's January Patch Tuesday update, which has made it so that some PCs flat-out refuse to shut down or hibernate, no matter how many times you try.…
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a bug in Windows security updates affecting system shutdown/hibernation, which relates to how operating systems manage system states and data persistence—areas relevant to storage and retrieval technologies in forensic contexts.
